principle.description: How much observability do you have on your systems environments, inputs, outputs and behaviour. Do you have enough information on how your system runs to make improvements/solve problems

level 1.description: Just the basics you get from free from Cloudwatch, htop, task manager etc.
questions: Do you have to have to add lots of debug statements when there's a prod issue?
Prod issues often catch you off guard?
You have little idea of how much CPU/Disk/Memory/DB is being used?
You have no accurate handle on how many rpm your service is handling at a given time
You have no historical view on application performance

level 2.value: Basic instrumentation of portions of your stack
level 2.description: You should have some logging at least
questions: Do you at least have APM turned on
Are your application logs going into a log aggregation platform

level 3.description: You have to have really have some logging at least
questions: Are your server/infrastructure logs going into a log aggregation platform

level 4.value: Max Instrumentation and SLO driven dashboards
level 4.description: You can see and model your system behaviours.  You've got complete coverage of every transaction from start to finish.  Metrics aggregate into service quality dashboards and alerting systems
questions: Can you quickly triage issues and hone in on problems very shortly after they arise
Do you have multiple overlapping views on system health
Do you have aggregate metrics that link to SLOs (SLAs)?
Do you have a good view on what "normal" looks like in terms of system behaviour
Do you have balanced and continuously tweaked alerting on abnormal system behaviours?
Can you easily track the effect of a release to production?
Do you have extensive system dashboards that are used by technical and non-technical alike on a regular basis

principle.description: Enable Fast Flow from development to production and reliable releases by standardising work, reducing variability and batch sizes
questions: Continuous Improvement
Continuous Integration
Continuous Delivery

level 1.description: You should really have some CI/CD at least
questions: Do you release multiple times an month?
Your lead time for changes is between 1 week and 1 month
Your Change failure rate is between 31-45%

level 2.description: You should have some CI/CD at least
questions: Do you release multiple times a week?
Your lead time for changes is between 1 week and 1 month
Your change failure rate is between 0-25%

level 3.description: You have to have really have some CI/CD at least
questions: Do you release multiple times a day?
Your lead time for changes is between 1 day and 1 week
Your change failure rate is between 0-20%

level 4.description: You need maximum really have some CI/CD at least
questions: Do you release multiple times an day? > 20 times
Can you confidently deploy on a Friday?
Your lead time for changes is between 1 hour and 1 day
Your change failure rate is between 0-10%

principle.description: This section highlights cultural styles and values within the company
questions: How good is your culture?

level 1.description: Very limited scope of responsibility, minimal cooperation, novelty is not welcomed, information is hidden
questions: Do team members feel fear of asking for feedback?
Is there a punitive culture?
Is cross-communication discouraged?
Do employees have little responsibility?
Is information readily available?

level 2.description: Modest cooperation, rule-following behaviour, narrow responsibility, novelty may lead to problems
questions: Is the organisation fair?
Does novelty leads to problems?
Focus on departemental goals
Failure leads to seek justice
Is information shared?
Is there trust across the organisational hierarchy?
Is cross-functional collaboration encouraged?
Is communication transparent?
Are new ideas welcomed?
Are risks shared?
Is there a focus on organisational goal?
Is work recognised as meaningful?
Is cross-functional collaboration established?
Is innovation sought and implemented?
is there a match between personal and organisational values?
Is failure seen as an opportunity to improve the system?
